commentBody: A clever theme quickly done.  A pleasure of a Tuesday puzzle.
What debate? It's pronounced puhKAHN üòä
The Dog Days get their name from the constellation Canis Major, not the star Sirius, which is not a constellation but part of Canis Major.
This was my easiest non-Monday solve yet!

Was this easier than Monday‚Äôs? I finished it much quicker. I thought LATENT implied something that eventually emerges? I‚Äôm not sure that ‚Äúuntapped potential‚Äù is the same as ‚Äúlatent potential.‚Äù Am I wrong? Latency usually means some kind of delayed signal in the audio world. Also, I‚Äôve been pronouncing it PEE-CAN and don‚Äôt intend to stop!

Interesting thing about Kansas City:

KC's major pro sports teams, including Mr. KELCE's, are named after monarchs of a sort. The baseball team is the Royals, the football teams the Chiefs, and the basketball team, since departed to Sacramento, was the Kings.  The Kansas City Monarchs were a longtime member of baseball's Negro Leagues.
ROGERMILLER also fit perfectly in 65A
This puzzle‚Äôs only LATENT-cy was an either including great American icons and ending with Kelce rather than Swift.

Congratulations on your debut, Mr. Shellito.

How very creative, having themed clues instead of answers. 
It made for a puzzle that was a joy to solve.

Thank you much!
Congrats on your debut, Kevin! A fun and clever puzzle. Loved the newspaper theme.

Back in the frontier days of the NYT, I submitted an ad for what was, at the time, a novel leg strap, coated with an antivenom, I manufactured for the all-too-common snake bite of the prairies.

It never ran.

The rejection telegram from the editor said:

‚ÄúAs a policy, we don‚Äôt mention things that could cut our circulation. Stop.‚Äù

(I‚Äôll show myself out.)

Sixty-five across?  Swift choice, and there were lots of them in the puzzle, but no less fun that it was quickly done. Many "now what??" clues that needed crosses for the fills and they always brought a smile.  

Very nice debut Kevin L. Shellito.  More please.

[San Francisco examiner], as it relates to FORTY NINER, might actually be a reference to the team‚Äôs medical examiner, if you‚Äôve had a look at the football roster‚Äôs injury report as of this evening üò¨ 

No matter. Bring on PAUL REVERE‚Äôs Patriots! (And we will see Mr. KELCE on October 20th.)

Fun puzzle! Kevin L. Shellito

Awesome debut, and the themers are very good indeed, there are probably only a few other newspapers that lend themselves to this theme. I thought of: [USA today?] FIFTY STATES [Paris match?] THE FRENCH OPEN [Philadelphia inquirer?] BEN FRANKLIN [Wall Street journal?] THE BIG SHORT [New York post?] ERIC ADAMS* [Jewish chronicle?] THE OLD TESTAMENT [Chicago Tribune?] BARAK OBAMA But I can think of multiple arguments against the inclusion of any of the above. My only slight unease is that the Boston Herald is relatively unknown compared to the Globe, but who can think of anything that can be clued [Boston globe?]? Also, learning how many darn ants there are, I'm like whoa that's where we need to sign up voters, promise them ant-farm subsidies, multiple NACHO chip spills and ice cream cone drops, and a relaxation of child labor laws. And we don't discriminate between black ants, carpenter ants, red ants, even yellow crazy ants. But termites, you can stay home. Eels swimming backwards, next you'll tell me they can hit the ball like Shohei Ohtani. I'll believe anything. Sprockets saying "Ants ants ants!": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2bLcilzeqc

Crossing three sports answers in the SE is a Natick for me.

(But I'm sure Barry will tell me why I'm wrong.)

‚ÄúSo you make these puzzles ‚Ä¶ who solves them?‚Äù

Thousands do today, congrats Kevin!
Alice Walker has gone down the rabbit hole (to use a different Alice metaphor) of conspiracy theories and antisemitism. I find it jarring to see her name in use without some kind of asterisk.
I really, really liked this puzzle, but I can‚Äôt remember this many three- and four-letter words.

I found this a very fun and clever puzzle.  Even though there were sports questions, I managed to solve it without cheats.

I hope to see more puzzles by Shellito!

Always thought Hoosier meant Vermont and having Plans rather than SCANS was getting frustrated why Google wasn't finding the Montpelier Palers.

Got there in the end.

I got ANT without any crossings because I know that, based on estimates and rounding and such, the combined biomass of ants and humans is roughly the same. (I researched this when writing a lesson on scientific notation.) https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-29281253
As a non-American, I was pleased to be able to work out 17, 31 and 49 across without cheating. I did have to cheat for 65 across though.

Congratulations on a fine NYT debut, Mr. Shellito! Your theme was amusing, though I can‚Äôt help but wonder what you could do with, say, the Ft. Worth Star-Telegram. 

I hope we‚Äôll see you back here soon.
Kevin‚Ä¶ such witty clues!  Bravo!
As an Australian who doesn't know a single thing about American history, or American media, this was a toughie!

Super USeteric but solvable in well below average time. 

Somehow more pleasing that way ‚Ä¶

Thanks.

Re Caitlin‚Äôs reference to ‚Äúink-stained wretch‚Äù, I was fascinated to explore all of the supposed originators of the term from various centuries, including the 18th (Samuel Johnson), 19th (Charles Dickens) and 20th (Trent Frayne, a long-time sports writer for the Globe & Mail).  Just goes to show you how dangerous it can be to rely on the internet for research.

(And there will no doubt come a time when the word ‚Äúink‚Äù will itself be a term that no-one understands and has to resort to the internet ‚Äî or, more likely, some new-fangled technology that makes the internet seem to the world as quaint as what the quill and pen seems to be to us today ‚Äî to understand.)

Well, it looks like the EMUs don't like the oh so clever way I expressed myself in a previous post.

So I'll simply say that the clue for 9D, technically, is incorrect.  

Sirius is not a constellation.  It is a star in the constellation Canis Major, or "Big Dog". 

*That's* why those are called the dog days.

I'm pretty sure everyone here knew that. 

But I just have to point that out, as a amateur astronomer for the past 65 years.
Especially fun for a Tuesday puzzle!
Really neat puzzle filled with entertaining clues. Personnel investments and sampled a beet were especially nice.

Reading the constructor‚Äôs note on his creative process gave me pause to think. Tearing at breakneck speed to solve these delicate webs of language is certainly a lot of fun.
But it could also be seen as akin to chugalugging a bottle of very fine wine.
Some things are meant to be savored. 
You‚Äôve changed my perspective today, Mr. Shellito.
Take time out to smell the roses. Don‚Äôt let the emu‚Äôs bite.

I‚Äôll echo other non US solvers; that was tough for us foreign types. I completed without understanding any of the theme clues before reading Wordplay, which does take away a level of enjoyment.

My one tiny nit; a London lad would not be called a CHAP, though I understand the logic behind the clue. Bloke would be a better fit, or geezer perhaps.  Don‚Äôt mind me grumbling, just trying to salvage my tattered wits after a brutal Tuesday solve. Good grid.
Delightful theme, Kevin‚Äîthanks for a lovely start to the day!

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Kevin.

There exists in NH a newspaper called the Union Leader.  I can't say I recommend it, but:

Union leader? has so many options.

George  Meade
Mother Jones
Eugene Debs
C√©sar Ch√°vez

Fun puzzle. Glad to see a new constructor. Was appropriately puzzled early on, but finally caught on to the trick. Just had to work the crosses for each of the theme answers to finally dawn on me but that just made for a an enjoyable workout.

Looking forward to more from Mr. Shellito. 

..

Although I'm not really familiar with US newspapers, it didn't take me long to grasp the theme. The answers to the clues were also familiar enough to a Canadian that I didn't struggle at all.

Except for TRAVIS KELCE.... I would have no idea at all who that was if it weren't for Taylor Swift.

A very clever theme, and one that I enjoyed solving!

A quick and fun puzzle..I found it  a bit surprising to find Travis Kelce among the historical figures. I tried to think of a Western lawman as the answer..like Wyatt Earp...but of course that was the wrong length.

Nice debut!

And it‚Äôs pronounced 

Pee-KAHN.

I pe-can‚Äôt permit pee-can.


No emus in Pekin, IL.

Help, fam! Yesterday my streak was at 85¬†‚Äî and this morning it's at 6. The puzzle archive shows last Tuesday's puzzle incomplete, but I know for sure I finished it (I remember BLOODTYPO made me smile). I realize how not-important-in-the-real-world this is ... but how can I correct my streak? TIA.

Gold star day.... so we like the puzzle.

Thank you Kevin and partner.  Nice job.

And, no little Tuesday tricks.

From starting-to-construct-crosswords to published-Times-puzzle in less than two years ‚Äì impressive.

Also impressive ‚Äì this theme, never done before, creative and playful.  Born out of true constructor thinking, with Kevin looking at the terrific [Washington post?] for VALLEY FORGE, an answer in one of his rejected puzzles, and thinking, ‚ÄúWhat else can I do with this?‚Äù  

A wordplay theme buttressed by non-theme wordplay clues/answers: [Like a drive through the woods?] for ERRANT.  [Not my typo] for SIC, and the terrific [Personnel in vestments] for CLERGY.

There are puns that make my eyes roll, and puns that make me go ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù and dwell for a moment in appreciation.  These three are in the latter camp, and between them, the theme, and the interesting factoids Kevin threw in, I loved this puzzle!

Some lovely words sprinkled about as well ‚Äì ERRANT, LATENT, VACATE ‚Äì and I liked seeing ANT cross a backward ANTE.

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Kevin.  I hope to see more from you ‚Äì please?  This one made me feel good all over ‚Äì thank you!

[EST and EDT]
[Having forty-two days left until the general election]









NY TIMES
USA TODAY
(Register; and VOTE!)

Re the mini
I know a cap is a hat - but no-one puts on their baseball hat ‚Ä¶.
I found it kinda depressing that there are only 1,000 times more ants than the US debt.

I really liked this one! And yes, it was nostalgic‚Ä¶this Gen Xer misses the days of paging through the newspaper and picking up copies of other cities‚Äô papers when traveling. I used to collect them‚Ä¶not so easy anymore.

As far as I know, "nacho" is not a chip. Nachos are a dish made from tortilla chips, cheese, and sliced jalape√±os, heated until the cheese melts. Other toppings, such as salsa, sour cream, guacamole, olives, beans, ground beef, may be added. "Nacho cheese" is a vile processed cheese product, like orange liquid plastic, used to make nachos at sports venues and convenience stores.
Yeah for me, no look ups or clues used! (Rare opportunity for a boast). An omen to buy a lottery ticket? Next Virginia headline: MarkWinsMillion

As one who still gets the NYT and Philadelphia Inquirer delivered, I loved this newspaper themed puzzle. I thought VALLEYFORGE for Washington Post was inspired.  I also like the clue personnel in vestments, just because it sounded like personal investments.  All in all an average-ish Tuesday with a bright theme.
Nice! And TIL where nacho came from.

I always thought of the ? as marking wordplay, and today's puzzle is making me think I'm wrong. To me, TRAVIS KELCE is just a regular answer for Kansas City star. I feel like wordplay there would be ANTARES REID or PROXIMAHOMES

This puzzle has made me feel very nostalgiac for print newspapers.  The NYT stopped delivering to my area a few years ago, and I miss it terribly.  Besides having to print my puzzle every day, the reading experience is not the same. 

As someone who has trouble concentrating on one thing at a time, the distraction of seeing so many interesting things to read  can be overwhelming.  In the paper, I knew if I skipped ahead to read something, I could always come back to the page I was on and it would still be in the same place and I didn't have to worry about missing anything.  It made for a more relaxing and complete reading experience.  The only upside is that I no longer have to clean black smudge marks from every surface, but that was a small price to pay.

I really enjoyed this.  Love the clever and interesting theme -- and I also applaud  Kevin's cluing choices.  So much thought was put into finding something a little different and fairly unknown about ordinary things.  The number of ANTs, ye gods!  That science fair experiment -- perhaps "classic" to you, but not to me.  The chip named for its inventor (!)  A new clue for EEL after all this time, and an interesting one.  These clues do not fall off trees into a constructor's lap -- they have to be searched for in an effort to please and amuse us, the solvers.  To be able to enjoy this kind of cluing on a Tuesday is a very nice surprise.

An imaginative, fun theme too.  I sort of think that the FORTY NINERs did more panning and digging than they did examining -- but I could be wrong.  Anyway, I wish that all Tuesdays could be like this.

Well, well...wasn't that clever?!  But no clue with The Plain Dealer??  No "San Jose messenger?"

It occurs to me that this is a puzzle for us Oldsters who remember The Funnnies, who turned to the ads to look for a job or find a worker, and who laughed with Molly Ivins and Art Buchwald.  

31A doesn't entirely work for me unless someone else has a take I couldn't come up with...

Oh, and there's something way better than vinegar and baking soda for a volcano...  I can't remember the substance, but I think I got it at a drug store, and we lit it with a match!  Living dangerously...    and truthfully, you can't really recreate the experience--the NOISE, the HEAT, the oozing, inexorable  MENACE of the lava flow--and the enduring heat and sulphuric steam from vents even decades after a flow has ceased.  
Not something you forget.  (I was in 7th grade--only a few years back!  Honest!  I think the paper on Oahu was the "Honolulu Star.")

This was very fun. I really love print newspapers, and it breaks my heart that we have mostly lost them. Also, my hillbilly dogs, (two blueticks) belong to a fancy dog park called the Dog Star Ranch. So Sirius is a familiar word around here. Really satisfying puzzle.

Just once I'd like to see Alice Walker clued to the musical genius behind AlicebanD, although I recognize that cluing 39A as [Walker, singer/songwriter for AlicebanD] is problematic. I can't pick one song as my favorite, but this is their first music video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7dHwWWXfwng Check it out or look for AlicebanD on you favorite music service. She's amazing. What's a girl like her gotta do to get famous? Steal Travis Kelce away from what's-her-name? (For the record, I like what's-her-name)

A quick search for Sirius tells me I'm the first and I get to be everything we've all been wanting to be:  PEDANTIC!!! !!!

The clue for 9D "9D [Hot summer period named for the constellation Sirius]  is wrong!

Sirius is a star, not a constellation.  The constellation it's in is *runs and checks Google real quick just to avoid appearing to be a total jerk* Canis Major.  That's why they're the Dog Days--because of the constellation Big Dog.

It totally ruined my solve.  Couldn't get past that and just was barely able to read another clue, or even begin to come up with an answer if I did.

In fact, now I've given up all hope for a better tomorrow

/s.

This is my 4th NYT crossword, participating from London. Yes, there are some clues I just can‚Äôt get, ever, especially anything to do with baseball, US football etc and some TV programmes, but it‚Äôs all good fun, and I accept that I will have to reveal some clues. And the spelling ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶  I also didn‚Äôt realise there might be a theme. Will keep trying.

Late addendum. Thought of an old joke, inspired by 51d. Maybe could be a crossword clue/answer sometime. Anyway...

"Father from Indiana?"

HOOSIERDADDY

I'll shut up now. 

...
So, what exactly is a Forty Niner examining? A potential gold panning site? Seems to be a very iffy clue at best.
Hehe!

I guess I need to start reading the credits at the end of the movie. I just watched Dune 2, but didn't know who Zendaya was. I still wouldn't have gotten RUE from that clue, having never heard of "Euphoria" either. McClanahan, maybe. (Yes, I watched Golden Girls.) My usual rant follows: too much content out there!

I've got no problem with the US-centricism of the theme - I think these clues were fun even if I didn't know them all and needed the crossings to help. And it is an American crossword after all. But the crossing of Beltway Bigwigs and Hoosier Hoopers is quite cruel. For those not familiar with slang terms for different regions, this is already tough. To add insult to injury, some of us just do not know our sports, and also nobody actually says POLS, do they? I have certainly never heard or read it in the wild.

Lovely puzzle, Kevin, more please!

I was trying to think of answers for 
Philadelphia inquirer?
Atlanta constitution?
but dull Tuesday brain was not forthcoming.

I've heard so many discussions of pee-PEE-can-CAN-kahn-KAHN that I can no longer remember which pronounciation is correct (Georgian) and which is wrong (dayum Yankee).

However, Strands was in my wheelhouse.
Strands #205
‚ÄúSpacing out‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

I think i'm still asleep, but a bunch of these made very little sense to me....notably 17A, 31A, 48A, 51A, 18D, and 51D (I do not know sports like, at all). Anyone care to explain these to me? 

Needless to say I had to use some lookups
I LOVED this one - fun and fresh!

I was a Bulletin boy. For me, there was only one Philadelphia newspaper‚Ä¶the Evening Bulletin. Went round the neighborhood throwing the Bulletin at people‚Äôs porches. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=fXSyCPongjA&pp=ygUkdGhvc2Ugd2VyZSB0aGUgZGF5cyBteSBmcmllbmQgbHlyaWNz
Cheers to us, the ink-stained wretches! :-D

Very enjoyable puzzle that showed a lot of TLC all around but this one took the cake for me... 

Or at least the communion wafer:

72A - Personnel in vestments for CLERGY!

Insert PADding here!
Terrific debut puzzle, and I‚Äôm looking forward to your next one, Mr. Shellito. It was fun and fresh, and I really enjoyed the clever theme.
A cool, clever puzzle. It gave me a little more trouble than it should have -- guess I'm just getting old.
Awesome! üòé Loved these newspaper üóûÔ∏è clues.
In addition to Truman working at the Kansas City Star, Ernest Hemingway got his start there.
Liked 44A and 46A.  SLEETS and SALT.
I had no idea why it was FORTYNINER. I knew that was a sports team and I filled it in because it fit, but I had no idea it was a gold rush reference.
[Sampled a beet] might be my most favoritest clue ever.

(Not my typo) was a great clue! I laughed as I typed it in.  The best definition of [sic] ever! Bravo.  Sports is not in my wheelhouse, so it took me a little longer to finish, but I was able to fill in enough on cross to get the right answers. Nice Tuesday puzzle. Time for me to go "sample a beet, say".  Cheers!
Theme answers were pretty opaque to this non-USian!

"Hella" was one of the words in an article, IIRC, in this paper, that guessed where I grew up within about 30 miles. "Crawdad" was another. If I had not gone back to college later in life to Sacramento, I would have missed "hella" because it is a newish term. BTW, there is some debate about whether it is related to the word hell. Many pronounce it more like "hullah".

I loved this puzzle so much that I'm here on Wednesday morning to say so (even though I solved it yesterday morning). 

I had the sensation of simultaneously feeling elated to be so in sync with the constructor's wavelength, and a little sad to be flying through the grid so quickly.

Great debut, Kevin! Such a clever, perfectly-tuned-for-Tuesday theme! And I enjoyed the constructor notes as well. 

There were some fun "mini themes", too: yummy Middle Eastern flavors of baba ghanouj, tahini and PITA; plus New England represented with RISD, the Massachusetts state tree, and of course the Boston Herald plus the "heralder" PAUL REVERE. 

I look forward to seeing a Kevin  L. Shellito puzzle again soon!
Loved this one, and I solve all my puzzles in newsprint in my daily paper. There‚Äôs no better way!

@Mark Merriam-Webster and I disagree: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pecan I can't even say for sure which one I use most often, but I think that it may vary, whether I'm talking about the pie variety or just the nut by itself. The derivation, most directly from "American French", would support your contention, but honestly, none of the three pronunciations given to me sounds best or sounds worst.

@Fact Boy The Old Farmers‚Äô Almanac would beg to disagree, but what do I know compared to our FB. ‚ÄúThe phrase ‚ÄòDog Days‚Äô conjures up the hottest, most sultry days of summer. The Old Farmer‚Äôs Almanac lists the traditional timing of the Dog Days: the 40 days beginning July 3 and ending August 11, coinciding with the heliacal (at sunrise) rising of the Dog Star, Sirius. The rising of Sirius does not actually affect the weather (some of our hottest and most humid days occur after August 11), but for the ancient Egyptians, Sirius appeared just before the season of the Nile‚Äôs flooding, so they used the star as a ‚Äúwatchdog‚Äù for that event.‚Äù The wiki entry seems to agree: https://tinyurl.com/5fhp4twe

@Fact Boy - Yet again, you have your facts wrong. 

The origin is most certainly from Sirius. It is a translation from the Latin term caniculares dies, which translates as "days of the dog star."

@Charles Nelson Reilly 

You probably don't pronounce it PEE-CAN, which would imply that both syllables are stressed.

Is it PEE-can or pee-CAN?  Or pee-KAHN?  Or puh-KAHN?  Or...

Never mind...

@Charles Nelson Reilly 

By the way, a PEE-CAN sounds like what they gave me in the hospital when I couldn't get out of bed to go to the bathroom.


!!!


!!!

@Steve L 

He could stress both syllables. However if he does, he‚Äôs not saying one word but two. Since, he‚Äôs not referring to a Pecan but a makeshift urine receptacle; probably safest to decline any food offerings.

@Steve L oops, I meant PEE-can. Although the more I‚Äôm saying it, the more unsure I am about my above statement re can vs kahn. I may have attempted to pronounce it PEE-kahn in the past. It‚Äôs starting to drive me a little nuts, so I‚Äôd butter stop.

@Red Carpet 

Way ahead of you, buddy!


(See just above your comment.)


!!!


!!!


!!!

@Andrzej 

And that was the only KC team I didn‚Äôt know.  Had to look it up. Didn‚Äôt include it because it didn‚Äôt fit the pattern, and soccer isn‚Äôt really one of the ‚Äúbig four‚Äù in the US anyway. I did amend my original post before sending it from ‚ÄúALL the teams in KC‚Ä¶‚Äù

Soccer teams have a naming pattern that doesn‚Äôt match up with our North American sports. We have two Nee York teams; one is named for an energy drink (the Red Bulls) and the other is simply NYCFC (I don‚Äôt have to spell it out, I‚Äôm sure).  And they play on a ‚Äúpitch‚Äù, which is often just a field (baseball, football) that is repurposed. And their games doesn‚Äôt end 1-nothing, 2-nothing, etc.; they end 1-nil, 2-nil or even nil-nil. 

Go figure.

@Andrzej North American soccer teams do imitate the names of teams across the pond, and in some cases it makes sense and in others it doesn't. Inter Miami makes sense as there is a sizable Spanish-speaking population in Miami. On the other hand, Atletico Ottawa seems very odd on the surface, until you learn that the team was founded by Atletico Madrid.

@Steve L 

I feel you. Football (as in, soccer) is supposedly our national sport (I say supposedly because we suck at it internationally), and even though I have never been a great fan, I've seen hundreds of games over the years - and yet I still don't understand much of the lingo. That's the thing with jargons, isn't it.
@Shellz Wow, you're dating yourself! (For those who don't follow:) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NBeXnzjvMrk !!!
@Shellz I was born in the 80s, and had ROGERMILLER for 65A, thanks to my father's records. Was very disappointed to realise what the actual answer was...

@Striker

Should be the Santa Clara Forty-Niners, along with:

Landover Commanders
Arlington Cowboys
East Rutherford Giants
Inglewood Rams
Orchard Park Bills
East Rutherford Jets
Miami Gardens Dolphins
Paradise Raiders

@kkseattle 

I went to my first game at Levis Stadium (in Santa Clara) this preseason. My 6 year old daughter participated in the Junior Gold Rush program and performed at half time with 150 other little girls from all over The Bay. 

The little cheerleaders impressed me quite a bit. Our stadium, on the other hand, did not. It was shiny but it felt rather soulless. Can‚Äôt help but think what might have been if they stayed in SF, and built the stadium that city deserves. SF Giants stadium sets the standard for how to do it right.

You‚Äôve got a good thing going up there at Lumen. Always an intimidating away game with that crowd noise.

@john ezra 

* Re Eric Adams, 

he might not hold his New York post for very long, that's what some people are saying.




Too political for you, emus? We shall see...
@john ezra - There is a very large globe in Boston! The Mapparium at the Christian Science Center is something to see. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mapparium

Hours after me my wife woke up. I told her about my troubles with today's puzzle. Apparently, to her "beltway" is a gimme, and she answered POL instantly when I read the clue to her. How can she bear living with a man so inferior to her in so many ways I will never truly understand.

However, I am much more of a Swiftie than her - she has never heard of TRAVIS KELCE.

@Andrzej 

Well, join the club.  You're in good company, those with a partner smarter than we are.
@Andrzej To be fair, NYT crossword compilers do have an unhealthy obsession with exam names...

@Tim 

Right?

You wouldn't happen to be an enchanter, btw? :D





[Additonal space, the Holy Grail of moderation evasion]

@Al  in Pittsburgh Brat is absolutely uniquely American! It wouldn't make sense to shorten it that way in German, because it comes from the verb "braten" and describes the way the "Wurst" is made (I don't know the grammatical term for a prefix like this). 
And, as Andrzej already replied, Oktoberfest is really strictly in Munich (although there are some cheap replicas in some other towns). Most people here try to avoid it because it is so touristy, we mostly prefer our local "Volksfest" or "Kirchweih" or one of the other million names for when you get together in a tent to drink beer and sing :D

@Anne 

I really like the German and Austrian Feste/Kirchtage/etc.! We visited several small and large ones in southern Germany and in the Austrian Alps - usually by chance - and they were all a true joy. The festively dressed locals (I really appreciate that some women put on Lederhosen these days, without feeling forced to go out in a Dirndl!), the simple yet special food, the music, the cheerful atmosphere - so great! As tourists we tried not to intrude but rather do as the locals did, and we always enjoyed ourselves üòÄ
@Andrzej oh please let your revenge be to submit a puzzle with Polish history answers and let the rest of us broaden our knowledge!

@Kris H It is something I have been contemplating, but... 1. I have no idea how to construct a puzzle and I can't be bothered to learn :D 2. I am not a vengeful person, with very few exceptions (and none relating to puzzle constructors or solvers) 3. Even if I ignored the two points above, I would not want to bombard decent people with trivia they could not possibly know, for the most part The only solution to the last problem would be to include some Polish trivia, but make it all gettable from American gimme crosses. As in, to have a word like "barszcz" (our spelling of the soup you know as borscht) crossing with RBI, NCAA, OREO, TDS, ADZ(E), CST and AZ. Also, this article is not perfect but it does provide a quick rundown of Polish history: https://culture.pl/en/article/learn-the-history-of-poland-in-10-minutes I could write some short version myself, and maybe I will get to it one day. I'll sooner do that than construct a puzzle ;) There also some brief Polish histories on Youtube but I hate (strong word but very accurate in this case) short videos so I can't be bothered to check and tell you if they are worth anything (given the quality of social media material - probably not very much).

@Andrzej 

In the US, kielbasa is a very specific sausage which also goes under the name "Polish sausage".  Anyone who stops and thinks must realize that there have to be many different types of sausage in Poland, just like anywhere else, but that's what we have.  

Many other sausages have German names, like bratwurst, knockwurst, weisswurst, etc., and we have Italian sausage, chorizo, longaniza, andouille, etc.  

I wonder if you know what specific sausage we Americans call kielbasa.

@Andrzej To echo what Steve L pointed out, ‚Äúkielbasa‚Äù is huge over here. The wiki entry suggests it most closely resembles what you may call ‚Äú Wiejska‚Äù sausage, but here it is made not just of pork but of just about anything (turkey kielbasa is very popular). There is a famous sandwich from Cleveland called ‚ÄúThe Polish Boy‚Äù which involves our kielbasa on a bun smothered with French fries and barbecue sauce and coleslaw. See: https://tinyurl.com/yfc427x5

@Hardroch 

Also, the sandwich in the Wikipedia article looks like a victim of a very bad road accident. Is that considered appetizing? And to have a whole link of sausage in a bun... Jesus. No wonder the US has one of the shortest average life spans among rich nations. The Polish way is to use several slices, and even that is not healthy.

@Andrzej  - I am lucky to live near a Polish shop that smokes its own meat. I've learned that what we call kielbasa is wiejska, as Hardroch gathered from Wiki. The shop sells several other types, but always suggests wiejska when I tell them what I'm cooking.

@Andrzej while Oktoberfest is indeed only a Munich thing, fall festivals around October are very common in other towns in Germany.  You will find that they are very similar to Oktoberfest in that there‚Äôs beer, food, rides, and games.  The biggest one I‚Äôve been to outside of Oktoberfest is the Bergkirchweih in Erlangen.

@Laura "Forty-niner" was a term for people who migrated to California, either temporarily or permanently, as a part of the gold rush (most of whom did so in 1849, hence the term.) As gold prospectors, yes, that's about what they did.

The common English name of the star Sirius is, and has been for many centuries, the Dog Star. The dog days are named for the Dog Star aka Sirius, not for the constellation (of otherwise fairly boring stars) in which it is found.

Sirius comes from the Greek word for ‚Äúscorching‚Äù and its overwhelming brightness was thought to heat the north as a kind of second sun.

@Helena 17A and 31A are explained in the column as theme clues, and 18D is explained in the column under tricky clues. For your other questions...

48A [Single or double] refers to two types of HITS in baseball - a single lets you run one base forward and a double lets you run two bases forward. 51A [Beltway bigwigs] uses a shortening of politicians, POLS, to describe the people in power ("bigwigs") in the US capital/DC region (also called the "Beltway"). 51D [Hoosier hoopers] is asking about a basketball team ("hoopers") whose members are based in Indiana (residents are called "Hoosiers"), so the Indiana PACERS fit the bill. Hope that helps!

@Mean Old Lady @Remy

It‚Äôs a play on the concept of music sampling. When a music producer uses pieces of a different composition in their new one it‚Äôs called sampling. Rap tracks (or compositions) are often called beats so if you sampled another rap song that song would be a sampled beat.
